Brahma King!
It is like this, like this.
Sentient beings in the world have no wisdom and no understanding regarding all dharmas. They are unable to comprehend and are covered by the darkness of ignorance. This is called ignorance.
From the condition of ignorance, formations arise. There are three kinds of formations, namely, those of body, speech, and mind.

Furthermore, from the condition of formations, consciousness arises. Consciousness has six kinds, namely, eye-consciousness, ear-consciousness, nose-consciousness, tongue-consciousness, body-consciousness, and mind-consciousness.
From the condition of consciousness, name-and-form arises.
Name refers to the four kinds of dharmas excluding form, namely, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness.
Form refers to the four great elements and all dharmas with form, which arise from the four great elements.
Such are the two kinds, the aggregate of form and the aggregate of name, which are called name-and-form.

From the condition of name-and-form, the six sense bases arise. The six internal sense bases have six kinds, namely, the eye sense base, ear sense base, nose sense base, tongue sense base, body sense base, and mind sense base.
From the condition of the six sense bases, contact arises again. There are six kinds of contact, namely eye contact, ear contact, nose contact, tongue contact, body contact, and mind contact.
Moreover, from the condition of contact, feeling arises. There are three kinds of feeling, namely pleasant feeling, painful feeling, and neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling.
Moreover, from the condition of feeling, craving arises. There are three kinds of craving, namely craving for desire, craving for form, and craving for the formless.

Moreover, from the condition of craving, grasping arises. There are four kinds of grasping, namely grasping at desire, grasping at views, grasping at precepts and observances, and grasping at a doctrine of self.
Moreover, from the condition of grasping, becoming arises. Becoming is of three kinds, namely desire-becoming, form-becoming, and formless-becoming.

From the condition of becoming, birth occurs. As for the dharma of birth, it refers to the realm of sentient beings, where the aggregates arise and cease in various distinctions, constantly changing and impermanent.
Taking birth as the basis, there are aggregates, elements, and sense bases, up to and including the factors such as the life faculty. This is called birth.

Taking birth as a condition, there is aging and death. As for aging, it refers to the mental consciousness becoming confused, the hair turning white, the face becoming wrinkled, the strength becoming weak, groaning and panting, the body becoming emaciated, up to and including the faculties all decaying. This is called aging.
What are the characteristics of death?

Death means that all beings, according to their realm and destiny, are subject to impermanence. The limit of life is exhausted, one abandons the warmth and touch, and after the life faculty ceases, the aggregates are also abandoned, and the four elements disperse. This is called death.
As explained above, aging and the factor of death are the two kinds.
What has been explained like this is called the analysis of the factors of dependent origination.
